Trial_Design.evidence: We randomized 69 knees to receive a TKA through either a midline or an anterolateral skin incision.

Intervention.evidence: We randomized 69 knees to receive a TKA through either a midline or an anterolateral skin incision.

Objective.evidence: We asked whether an anterolateral skin incision to the knee would decrease the area of skin hypesthesia and associated postoperative discomfort.

Method_Outcome.evidence: We assessed skin sensitivity by application of the Semmes-Weinstein monofilament at 13 reference points at 6 weeks and 6 and 12 months postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: We randomized 69 knees to receive a TKA through either a midline or an anterolateral skin incision.

Number_Randomised.evidence: We randomized 69 knees to receive a TKA through either a midline or an anterolateral skin incision.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The area of hypesthesia was less after an anterolateral compared with a midline incision up to 1 year after surgery: the areas of hypesthesia were, respectively, 32 cm 2 versus 76 cm 2 at 6 weeks, 14 cm 2 versus 29 cm 2 at 6 months, and 7 cm 2 versus 19 cm 2 at 1 year.
